templates.content:
Stuffing tubes, grinder plates, and knives are ordered according to head size, and our head sizes are standard. You can measure your current plate using our printable Measuring Chart: https://cdn.commercev3.net/cdn.lemproducts.com/downloads/LEM_grinder_plate_tips_final.pdf 

The head is the "L" shaped piece in which the meat is put into and extrudes out of. Many heads have a number imprinted on the side. You can also find the head size imprinted on the edge of the plate or the side of the knife.
templates.name: How do I figure out what size tube, knife, or plate I need for my grinder?

templates.content: To store a bag of natural casings after it has been opened, leave the unused casings in the bag with the brine, put them in an airtight container, and store them in the refrigerator. Refrigerating the casings will minimize the odor and keep them fresh longer. If you have soaked and flushed some casings and didn't use them, you can put them back into the bag with the other casings. Just pour salt over top of the casings and store them in the same manner.
templates.name: How do I store unused natural casings after the bag has been opened?

templates.content: To determine the size tube you need for your stuffer you would first measure the base of an existing tube. If you do not have a tube that fits your stuffer, measure the diameter of the interior of the retaining ring. The retaining ring is the "nut" that holds the tubes on the stuffer. After the base size is determined you will have to determine the size of casing you will be stuffing and purchase a tube of the correct diameter to fit inside the casing.
templates.name: How do I determine what size tube I need for my stuffer?

templates.content:
It depends on which casing you are using. The Natural Hog, Sheep, and Beef Casings must be rinsed several times in warm water, and then soaked for 1‚ÅÑ2-1 hour until soft and pliable prior to use.

Fibrous Casings must be soaked in warm water 20-30 minutes before stuffing. Collagen Middles and Collagen Rounds must be soaked for 3-5 minutes in cool salt water (ratio 1 gallon water to 1 cup un-iodized salt). However, Non-Edible Casings with smoked flavor, Edible Collagen Casings and our Hot Dog Casings require no preparation before they are used. Hope this helps!
templates.name: Is there preparation for the casings before use?

templates.content: To load the Poly Bag Tape machine, insert the tape on the star shaped tape holder. Pull the tape off the roll approximately 6" and place it in the machine sticky side up. Lay the tape over the slot in the top of the machine, making sure the tape is at least 2" past the end of the machine, and push a bag through the slot. When a bag is pushed into the slot, the tape will go into the slot. Seal the bag and be cut off. That's it! This will load the tape for future use. The unit should not require re-loading until a new roll of tape is installed.
templates.name: How do I load the tape on the Poly Bag Tape machine?

templates.content: The 1000 series has a stronger pump at 24Hg Pump compared to the 22Hg Pump of the 500 series. Its wattage is 880 Watts which is more than the 500 series which operates at 462 Watts. Generally speaking, what really sets the 1000 series MaxVac apart beyond these differences is its incredible run-time of 10 hours which is twice as much compared to the 500 series and it also comes with a warranty of 5 years instead of 2 years of the other version. Hope this helps!
templates.name: What is the difference between MaxVac 500 vs MaxVac 1000?

templates.content: Any type of lean meat will work, beef, venison, turkey, etc. For jerky and snack sticks the leaner the meat the better. When making sausage we suggest an 80:20 blend. 80% meat and 20% pork or pork fat. We do not recommend using suet in your sausage mix.
templates.name: What meat is recommended for making jerky and sausage?

templates.content: I'd recommend taking our quiz at the following link in order to find out which LEM Meat Grinder is perfect for you: https://www.lemproducts.com/best-meat-grinder
templates.name: Which meat grinder would you recommend?

templates.content: We recommend using 20% pork or pork fat to 80% lean meat. The fat is added to the meat to make up the total amount of meat needed. If you are making a 10 lb. batch of summer sausage you would use 8 lbs. of lean ground meat and 2 lbs. of pork fat. We do not recommend the use of suet in place of fat. Suet has a higher melting point than the sausage cooking temperature. When the meat is fully cooked the suet would not be melted completely, leaving suet particles in the sausage.
templates.name: Do I need to add fat to my sausage? What type of fat is suggested?

templates.content: There is a diagram available that shows which casing to use for which type of sausage you are making. You can check it out here: https://cdn.commercev3.net/cdn.lemproducts.com/downloads/casing_chart.pdf
templates.name: What casing do I need for the product I am making?

templates.content: Yes, we recommend using at least 1 oz. (2 tablespoons) of water per pound of meat with our Backwoods Seasoning.
templates.name: Do I need to use water when using Backwoods Seasoning? How much?

templates.content: The hand crank is Right Crank usage only. When installing the crank, position the stuffer so the crank is located on your right side as you face the unit. Install the cylinder so the stuffing tube is facing toward you. Then operate the unit by turning the crank with your right hand while guiding the tube with your left hand.
templates.name: Is the hand crank Left or Right handed on the Sausage Stuffer (Models #1111 & #1112)?
